'''Frank Mitchell Redington''' (10 May 1906 – 23 May 1984) was a noted [[United Kingdom|British]] [[actuary]]. Frank Redington was best known for his development of [[Immunization (finance)|Immunisation Theory]] <ref>Redington, F. M. (1952). Review of the Principles of Life Office Valuations. Journal of the Institute of Actuaries, vol. 78, pages 286-340.</ref> which specifies how a [[fixed income]] portfolio can be "immunised" against changing [[interest rates]].

He was born in [[Leeds]] and attended [[Liverpool Institute for Boys]], and [[Cambridge University]]. He joined the staff of the [[Prudential plc|Prudential]] [[life insurance]] company in 1928 and became its Chief Actuary in 1951, continuing in that capacity until his retirement in 1968.  

He was the Chairman of the Life Offices’ Association from 1956–1957 and president of the [[Institute of Actuaries]] 1958–1960.  In 2003, he was voted "the greatest British actuary ever" by readers of ''The Actuary'', the magazine for the actuarial profession.<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://www.the-actuary.org.uk/pdfs/03_12_greatest.pdf | title= The Greatest British Actuary ever| journal = The Actuary | pages=18 | date= December 2003|archiveurl=http://www.theactuary.com/archive/old-articles/part-4/the-greatest-british-actuary-ever-26-23174-3B/|archivedate=2014}}</ref>
